Article Title: Finance ministry weighs proposal for PSU general insurers' merger
Article Text: NEW DELHI: The finance ministry is considering an earlier proposal to merge the three state-owned general insurance companies into a single entity, following their improved financial health, to achieve better efficiency and scale.Government infused Rs 17,450 crore between 2019-20 and 2021-22 in three PSU general insurance companies, namely Oriental Insurance, National Insurance and United India Insurance, to bring them out of financial distress.In the Budget for 2018-19, the then finance minister Arun Jaitley announced that the three companies - Oriental Insurance, National Insurance, and United India Insurance - would be merged into a single insurance entity.However, govt dropped the idea in July 2020, and the Union Cabinet rather approved a capital infusion of Rs 12,450 crore into the three general insurance companies. As their finances have improved, the finance ministry is doing a preliminary assessment of the merger of these entities with a view to improving their efficiency, according to sources.Besides, the proposal to privatise a general insurance company, as announced by govt, is being examined, sources said, adding that various options are on the table, but nothing has been firmed up yet.It is to be noted that finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, while announcing the 2021-22 Budget, had announced a big-ticket privatisation agenda, including the privatisation of two public sector banks and one general insurance company.
Article Summary: Government infused Rs 17,450 crore between 2019-20 and 2021-22 in three PSU general insurance companies, namely Oriental Insurance, National Insurance and United India Insurance. As their finances have improved, the finance ministry is doing a preliminary assessment of the merger of these entities.

Article Title: Toxic smog chokes Delhi: Air quality turns 'severe' as AQI soars to 427 despite GRAP-III measures
Article Text:
Delhi Smog Worsens Two Days After Diwali, AQI Hits Very Poor Levels

(With agency inputs)

NEW DELHI: The national capital woke up to dense smog on Monday, with the average Air Quality Index (AQI) at 359 at 7 am — classified as 'very poor' — despite the Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP)-III being in effect across Delhi and the National Capital Region (NCR), according to the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB).A thick layer of smog continued to blanket Delhi on Monday, showing little improvement from Sunday’s AQI of 385.Bawana recorded the highest pollution level at 427, falling under the ‘severe’ category, while NSIT Dwarka reported the lowest at 225, according to the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB).Iconic areas like India Gate and Kartavya Path were shrouded in toxic smog, with AQI readings of 341 (‘very poor’). Other hotspots included Chandni Chowk (383), RK Puram (366), ITO (394), Punjabi Bagh (384), Patparganj (369), Pusa (365), and Dwarka Sector-8 (356).Meanwhile, Anand Vihar remained engulfed in a layer of toxic smog, with the CPCB reporting an AQI of 383, classified as ‘very poor’.The thick smog, along with deteriorating air quality, mercury continued to hover around the 9 Degree Celsius mark, with some areas recording even lower temperatures.As per CPCB classification, an AQI between 0-50 is considered 'good', 51-100 'satisfactory', 101-200 'moderate', 201-300 'poor', 301-400 'very poor', and 401-500 'severe'.Following the deteriorating air quality in the national capital, the Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP) III was implemented on November 11 across Delhi by the Commission for Air Quality Management (CAQM). The measures aim to control emissions through stricter restrictions on construction, vehicular movement and industrial operations.Under GRAP-III, restrictions include a ban on most non-essential construction, limits on BS-III petrol and BS-IV diesel vehicles, suspension of in-person classes for students up to Class 5 with a shift to online or hybrid learning, curbs on industries using non-clean fuels, and a ban on non-emergency diesel generators.Earlier, the Supreme Court directed the governments of Punjab and Haryana to file a status report on the measures taken to curb stubble burning, which contributes to the air pollution crisis in the Delhi-NCR region.A bench of Chief Justice of India BR Gavai and Justice K Vinod Chandran ordered, "We direct the state of Punjab and Haryana to file a report on what steps are being taken to curb stubble burning."Since Diwali, air quality in Delhi and the NCR has remained in the 'very poor' to 'severe' categories in several areas, despite Stage III of the GRAP being in effect.
Article Summary: The national capital woke up to dense smog on Monday, with the average Air Quality Index (AQI) at 359 at 7 am. Bawana recorded the highest pollution level at 427, falling under the ‘severe’ category, while NSIT Dwarka reported the lowest at 225.

Article Title: Building the insurer's second brain
Article Text:
(PC:FurtherAI)

Inside FurtherAI’s Bid to Rethink Insurance Workflows

You

in

that

resented

On a recent afternoon in San Francisco, Aman's grandmother called from Bhopal to tell him she had started using AI.She is 85, the kind of north Indian grandmother who still rises at four every morning for puja. So Aman Gour, co-founder and CEO of FurtherAI, did what any AI founder would do when his octogenarian nani announces a tech pivot.“What AI are you using?” he asked. “ChatGPT?”“No, beta,” she said. “Whenever I have questions, I call you.are my AI. Aman's Intelligence.”It’s a joke with a sharp little truth inside it. Long before large language models began absorbing the world’s PDFs, there were grandchildren on patchy phone lines answering questions about the internet and more importantly, WhatsApp settings. Intelligence, artificial or otherwise, has always been relational.FurtherAI, the company Aman now runs out of a new office that “looks like a regal insurance building,” is very muchthe business of building that relationship between machine and human into something practical: a kind of AI workspace for the people who keep the modern economy insured.If you’ve never thought about how insurance actually gets done, the industry is one of those invisible infrastructures (like sewers or DNS) that only makes headlines when something goes wrong.But for underwriters, brokers, and claims adjusters, the day-to-day reality is screens full of PDFs, spreadsheets, and emails.“We met these folks who are basically managing trillions in risk,” Aman told me. “And they’re spending their days copying numbers from one place to another.”To understand why somebody would devote their life to automating the unglamorous middle of commercial insurance, it helps to picture a boy in a kirana shop in Bhopal, sitting between two men who disagreed about time.One was his father, a shopkeeper who would later build a small empire of gas stations. For him, time was scarce. “You have 24 hours,” he told his son. “Get the best out of it.” Sundays were for work; that’s simply what adults did.The other was his grandfather, a teacher. Life is long, he would say. There is time.As a child, Aman sat on a low stool between the counter and sacks of grain, literally looking left and right at these two philosophies. On the wall, decades later, his grandfather would tape up a Times of India clipping of Ajay Banga and ask, “Aman, when are you going to come here?”Aman didn’t know, but the question lodged somewhere. It became, over time, the sentence he now carries around in his head: “Live micro, plan macro.” Work hard on the day in front of you; keep a larger pattern loosely in mind.The “micro” started with the well-worn Indian script: Bhopal to Kota for IIT coaching (“the infamous Bansal classes”), waking at 3:30 AM to stay ahead of an ocean of teenage ambition; from Kota to IIT Bombay for computer science; from there to a coveted job at Microsoft. He describes himself as more hard-working than brilliant, forever a little uneasy among the effortless prodigies who could do absurd mental math after three beers, but he kept finding ways to climb.Then, as tends to happen in stories like this, boredom and curiosity conspired. At Microsoft, he entered an internal hackathon, built something that did well, and realized he wanted to build entire products. He quit to start his first company, TurboHire, which used AI to automate recruitment workflows and eventually scaled to more than a million dollars in ARR.It was an innovative SaaS business that grew to over a million dollars in revenue and taught Aman how to build companies from scratch — and eventually, he exited and moved to the Bay Area to start the next chapter.When Aman and his eventual co-founder, Sashank Gondala, applied to Y Combinator, they did it with a different idea, though: AI for software testing. The idea made perfect sense to them; it, in fact, got them into the program. But sitting in the compressed, slightly feverish atmosphere of YC, listening to partners who had seen hundreds of start-ups either catch fire or quietly fade out, they were forced into a distinction.“Tom Blomfield told us there are zero-million-dollar companies and zero-billion-dollar companies,” Aman recalled, referring to the Monzo founder who is now a YC group partner. “In the beginning they both have zero in revenue. But one is built to go public, and one isn’t.”Their testing idea, they realized, was a zero-million. A nice business. Just notbusiness.There are easy ways to respond to feedback like that. You can decide the partner is wrong, double down on your vision, and keep going. More dangerously, you can pinball from idea to idea in what founders call “pivot hell,” never staying long enough with any of them to know if they actually work.The harder thing is to hold the steering wheel steady while you change the road beneath you.Blomfield’s advice was oddly specific: go look at vertical AI. Pick one industry with dense unstructured data, shrinking margins, and lousy tools. Commit to it for three months. Then decide.“We resisted at first,” Aman said. “We didn’t know anything. We didn’t know what lawyers do, what insurers do, what people in logistics actually do all day.”But he and Sashank also knew their own pattern. For nearly a decade, both had been working on workflow automation, getting machines to handle the boring parts of knowledge work.The insurance industry is built on documents: broker submissions, property schedules, loss runs, policy forms, endorsements. These documents arrive in every format imaginable (scanned PDFs, semi-structured Excel, email attachments), and then have to be reconciled, checked, and entered into systems that mostly don’t talk to one another. Meanwhile, the workforce is aging; one widely cited estimate suggests the American insurance industry could lose more than 400K workers by 2026, even as more than 3M professionals still spend most of their time on manual data entry and document review.Previously, there were two reasons this stayed stubbornly human: machines were bad at reading messy documents, and the rule trees required to model insurance logic were too brittle to maintain. Knowing when a “cat” was a catastrophe rather than an animal was not something you could embed in a template.The arrival of LLMs changed that calculus. If you could combine an LLM’s ability to read with a serious, industry-specific understanding of insurance, maybe you could build something more interesting than yet another dashboard. Think: An AI colleague of sorts who could do the grinding work and leave the humans to decide what to bind or decline.That, at least, was the hypothesis. To test it, they bought donuts.There is something faintly absurd about the co-founder of a Bay Area AI company driving around the Bay Area with a box of donuts, knocking on the doors of insurance agencies like a pharma rep in a previous era. But this is exactly what Aman did.“We literally went door to door,” he said, laughing. “Box of donuts, no appointments. ‘Hey, I know we’re disturbing your day, but can we talk to you about what you do?’”Part of the exercise was ethnographic. They needed to see, with their own eyes, how underwriters and brokers actually spent their days: where the spreadsheets lived, which PDFs they ignored until the last minute, which “systems of record” were silently bypassed by forwarding emails.Part of it was cultural. Insurance is still, in many lines, ‘a specific kind of individual’s relationship’ industry. As two South Asian founders from IIT Bombay with little formal background in insurance, Aman and Sashank needed to know if they could earn trust here, or if they would be better off chasing a different vertical.They found, somewhat to their surprise, that the relationship orientation worked in their favor. Agents and underwriters made time. People answered questions. The donuts probably helped. The discomfort of door-knocking gave way to a delighted discovery: these were pragmatic people who cared about their customers,their software, and had a clear sense of which tasks they would gladly offload.Those early days are still etched in the way Aman talks about the company. Insurance is not “slow to adopt technology,” he insists. The tech simply hasn’t been good enough, tailored enough, to justify the pain of change.“If we can build good tech that actually understands their world,” he said, “it should solve a lot of their problems.”Strip away the jargon, and FurtherAI’s core product is that it reads documents, moves data, and follows rules on behalf of insurance teams. The company calls it an “AI workspace for insurance”, a kind of operating layer that sits between a carrier’s email inboxes, rating engines, broker portals, and policy admin systems.Here’s one way to picture it.Imagine you’re an underwriter at a mid-sized specialty carrier. On Monday morning, you open your inbox to a dozen new submissions from brokers: each one a package of applications, engineering reports, loss histories, spreadsheets, and the occasional scanned PDF someone faxed in 2007. Your job is to decide which risks to quote, which to decline, and which to refer for more information.In the traditional workflow, you’d start manually extracting key data points: addresses, limits, deductibles, and prior losses into your underwriting workbench. You’d cross-check the numbers against your own guidelines: appetite by class and geography, aggregation limits, underwriting authority thresholds. For renewals, you’d dig up last year’s policy and compare terms clause by clause. All of this is mentally taxing.In the FurtherAI version of that day, the submissions are fed through an AI “teammate” that has been trained specifically on insurance documents. It knows that “cat” in a property schedule probably means catastrophe, not a pet. It can tell the difference between “named windstorm coverage excluded” and “windstorm deductible applies.” It parses the submissions, fills in the required fields in your internal systems, flags missing data, compares policies, and presents you with a clean summary plus exceptions.One of FurtherAI’s differentiators, and the reason they insist on calling themselves “insurance-native,” is that each customer uploads their own underwriting guidelines, rating factors, and routing rules. The AI learns those and applies them consistently, rather than imposing a standard model on everyone.Carriers and brokers using FurtherAI now process premiums each year through the platform, automating tasks from submission intake and policy comparisons to compliance checks and, increasingly, parts of claims handling.FurtherAI has gained enough traction that’s helped the company raise a $25M Series A in October, led by a16z, which brought its total funding to about $30M, one of the larger early-stage AI bets in the insurance space.Aman is fond of a simple metaphor when he talks about AI strategy. The smartest move, he argues, is to build what’s core, and buy what scales.Training the largest AI models now costs hundreds of millions of dollars and carries all the operational risk that implies. For most insurers, building a proprietary model end-to-end makes little sense. But buying a generic model and expecting it to understand the nuances of an engineering report, or a layered property program, is equally naïve.FurtherAI’s answer is to sit in between. The company uses a mix of large language models under the hood(a “multi-LLM stack” in the current jargon), but wraps them in insurance-specific data structures, workflows, and human-in-the-loop designs.For each client, a “forward-deployed” AI engineer works alongside underwriters or operations staff to map their current processes, tune the workflows, and agree on what the AI is allowed to do autonomously versus what should always be reviewed.Although the longer-term plan is still to be realized, the direction of travel is clear. McKinsey and others have started talking about “agentic AI”: systems that can string together multiple tasks to execute a workflow, and insurance, with its stable logic and paper-heavy processes, is a natural candidate.The question, then, is whether AI will show up as a blunt cost-cutting instrument, or as something closer to Aman's grandmother’s definition: a trusted second brain that lets humans do more of the work that actually matters to them.If Aman is the storyteller of FurtherAI, his co-founder, Sashank Gondala, is the engineer in the background making sure the story holds together.They met as undergraduates at IIT Bombay: Aman the hardworking generalist who threw himself into student politics and leadership roles, Sashank the one who simply “looked really smart.” Aman still calls him “the smartest person I’ve ever met,” and does so with incredible admiration.After IIT, Sashank went on to do a master’s in computer science with a focus on ML at GeorgiaTech, and then joined Apple as a language modeling scientist, working on the core models that power Siri. Every time Siri mangled Aman's name, he would send Sashank a teasing message. Gradually, the pair began to talk less about pronunciation and more about what else this kind of tech could do.The division of labor at FurtherAI is typical of many founder pairs: Aman sells; Sashank builds. But in industries like insurance, the fact that the person building the models has spent years sweating the edge cases of human language is part of the pitch.If you are not an underwriter in Cleveland or a broker in Dallas, you might reasonably wonder why you should care about the automation of insurance workflows.Part of the answer is pedestrian: cost. In most lines of insurance, somewhere between 25 and 40 cents of every premium dollar goes to operating expense: processing, administration, distribution. If AI-based automation can safely cut that expense ratio, the savings can show up as cheaper premiums or better coverage.Part of it is about resilience. Insurance is where many of society’s slow-burn crises show up first. Healthcare cost inflation becomes a set of choices about which drugs and procedures plans will cover. Each of these decisions is mediated through documents and workflows. Making those workflows faster and more transparent can make it easier for humans to see what they’re deciding.And part of it is about work itself. In almost every white-collar industry, there is a running argument about AI: will it replace us or help us? The unsatisfying but likely accurate answer is “both, depending.”What makes the FurtherAI story interesting, beyond the funding round and the logos on the slide, is that it takes seriously the idea that some work should disappear. Not the judgment calls, not the relationship building, but the cut-and-paste toil that, if you’re honest, no one will miss.There is still risk here. Automation can become an excuse for headcount reduction rather than a chance to invest in better service. AI systems are only as good as the data they’re trained on and the guardrails around them. Privacy and regulatory compliance in insurance are table stakes.Aman likes to joke that in one evening at a friend’s wedding, he found both his life partner and his work partner.He had gone reluctantly, pulled there by a phone call and “a lot of melodrama” from the groom, and ran into an old IIT classmate who was doing her MBA at Wharton. She tried to set him up with a friend. But he was interested in her. There were numbers exchanged, some via back-channels, and then, gradually, a relationship that would require a more consequential decision.At the time, Aman was running his first company in India. She would be in the Bay Area. So how would they make it work? “That’s the last thing I want to worry about,” he told her. “I’ll figure it out.”Moving countries for love meant leaving a company he had built, dealing with visas, and starting again in a place where his network was thinner. The old voices in the kirana shop (hurry up, life is long), were suddenly in tension again. He decided, as he tends to, by taking the next step and trusting the pattern.“When that happens in one evening,” he likes to say now, “imagine what can happen in a year.”There is a similar mixture of impatience and patience in how he talks about the future of FurtherAI. The near-term goal is audacious but conventional: build a billion-dollar company, take it public, justify the confidence of investors like Andreessen Horowitz and the early carriers who bet on them.The longer-term ambition is more modest and, in its way, more demanding: build something that his father and grandfather would recognize as worthwhile when they read about it in the paper. A company that makes the daily lives of people inside it kinder. And less frantic.On Saturdays, he doesn’t work. He and his wife have chai, take swing lessons at the golf range, sometimes go for a hike. He meditates more than he used to. The boy who grew up believing that Sundays were for the shop has chosen, consciously, to step away one day a week. The micro has shifted.In Bhopal, his grandmother still wakes up at 4 to pray, still calls her grandson with questions when she has them. She is amused by the idea that her off-hand description (“Aman’s Intelligence”) might be the kernel of his philosophy about AI. But it fits.If the future of work in insurance, or in any industry, is going to be mediated by machines that read, write, and act on our behalf, then the question isn’t just how powerful those machines are. It’s who they feel like when they pick up the phone.Aman’s bet, with FurtherAI, is that they should feel less like a black box and more like a trusted grandchild: someone who clears the busywork, remembers your rules, and gives you back the one resource his father and grandfather never stopped arguing about.Time.
Article Summary: Aman Gour is the co-founder and CEO of FurtherAI, a company that uses AI to improve insurance workflows. Gour grew up in Bhopal, India, between two men who disagreed about time. His grandfather told him, “Get the best out of it.”

Article Title: US-Venezuela tensions: Airlines cancel flights from Caracas; FAA warns of unsafe airspace
Article Text:
(AP)

Venezuela CUT OFF, U.S. Forces Surround Maduro; Global Airlines Halt Flights Ahead Of U.S. Attack

Multiple international airlines suspended their departures from Venezuela on Saturday, following a US aviation alert warning of unsafe conditions in the country’s airspace. The cancellations come amid heightened tensions as the United States prepares a new phase of operations targeting Venezuela, raising concerns about the stability of the region.Gol of Brazil, Avianca of Colombia and TAP Air Portugal pulled their scheduled flights from Caracas, according to Flightradar24 and updates from Simon Bolivar Maiquetia International Airport. Colombia’s aviation authority said there were “potential risks” for aircraft operating near Maiquetia because of worsening security and increased military presence in the area.TAP Air Portugal said its Saturday and upcoming Tuesday services would not operate. “This decision follows information issued by the United States aviation authorities, which indicates that safety conditions in Venezuelan airspace are not guaranteed,” the airline told Reuters.Spain’s Iberia also decided to pause flights to Caracas starting Monday, although the company’s Saturday service to Madrid took off.“The company will assess the situation to decide when to resume flights to that country,” its spokesperson said.Other airlines, including Copa Airlines and Wingo, continued their scheduled operations from the airport. Latam Airlines also canceled its Bogotá flight planned for Sunday, according to Flightradar24.The FAA notice cited the “worsening security situation and heightened military activity in or around Venezuela,” cautioning that the environment posed risks to civil aircraft at all flight levels. The advisory comes as the Trump administration increases its military presence in the Caribbean, including deploying a major aircraft carrier, multiple warships, and F-35 fighter jets.In addition to these maneuvers, four US officials told Reuters that Washington is preparing a new phase of operations against Venezuela, which could include covert actions aimed at weakening or potentially removing President Nicolás Maduro from power. All officials spoke on the condition of anonymity due to the sensitivity of the plans.Maduro, who has led Venezuela since 2013, has repeatedly accused the US of trying to unseat him and insists that Venezuelan citizens and the military are prepared to resist any foreign intervention.
Article Summary: Gol of Brazil, Avianca of Colombia and TAP Air Portugal pulled their scheduled flights from Caracas. Iberia also decided to pause flights to Caracas starting Monday. Colombia’s aviation authority said there were “potential risks” for aircraft operating near Maiquetia.

Article Title: Bitcoin crash: Price tumbles near $80,000; corporate crypto holdings hit hard
Article Text:
Representative image credits: IANS

Bitcoin fell sharply on Friday, closing at $80,553, while ether also hit a four-month low, as cryptocurrencies led a sell-off in riskier assets. Analysts warned that dropping below $80,000 could bring even bigger losses for the world’s largest digital currency.The decline comes amid investor concerns about expensive tech stocks and uncertainty over near-term US interest rate decisions. Cryptocurrencies, often seen as a measure of market risk appetite, have reflected weak sentiment in the markets, with AI-focused stocks falling and volatility rising.Bitcoin has lost 12% in the past week, wiping out its gains for the year, and ether is down nearly 19% so far in 2025. The drop comes after a strong rally earlier this year that pushed bitcoin above $120,000 in October, helped by favorable global regulations for crypto. Analysts said the market remains sensitive after last month’s record single-day liquidation of more than $19 billion in positions."If it's telling a story about risk sentiment as a whole, then things could start to get really, really ugly, and that's the concern now," said Tony Sycamore, market analyst at IG, as quoted by Reuters.The fall also puts pressure on crypto treasury companies, which hold large amounts of bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies on their balance sheets.Standard Chartered said a drop below $90,000 could leave around half of these holdings “underwater,” meaning the assets are worth less than what was paid. Some firms may need to raise funds or sell part of their holdings, which could push prices lower.Listed companies hold about 4% of all bitcoin and 3.1% of ether, according to Standard Chartered.Citi analyst Alex Saunders noted that $80,000 is an important level, around the average price that bitcoin is held at in exchange-traded funds. Market tracker CoinGecko said the total value of all cryptocurrencies has fallen by roughly $1.2 trillion in the last six weeks.Shares of crypto treasury companies have also dropped. Strategy (MSTR.O), the largest firm in this group, has seen its stock fall 61% since July, leaving it down nearly 40% for the year. JP Morgan said Strategy could be removed from some MSCI equity indexes, which could force further selling by funds that track the company. Japanese company Metaplanet (3350.T) has dropped about 80% from its June peak, according to Reuters.Brent Donnelly, president of Spectra Markets, said past bitcoin sell-offs in 2018 and 2022 saw prices fall 75% to 80%. If that happens again, bitcoin could drop as low as $25,000. "I am not saying we are in crypto winter. Just offering a reminder that 75%/80% drawdowns have been part of the game in bitcoin," he said.
Article Summary: Bitcoin closes at $80,553, while ether hits four-month low. Drop comes amid investor concerns about expensive tech stocks and uncertainty over near-term US interest rate decisions. Cryptocurrencies have reflected weak sentiment in the markets, with AI-focused stocks falling and volatility rising.

Article Title: 'Richest, strongest US has ever been': Donald Trump backs tariff push; takes dig at 'sleepy' Joe Biden
Article Text:
US President Trump (AP)

US President Donald Trump once again defended his aggressive tariff strategy, claiming it is generating “TRILLIONS of Dollars” for America and has functioned as a powerful tool to prevent international conflicts.In a Truth Social post on Sunday, Trump wrote, “We are taking in TRILLIONS of Dollars in Tariffs and Investment Dollars from foreign lands because of Tariffs. I have stopped 5 of the eight WARS directly because of the threat of Tariffs if they don’t stop fighting or, better yet, if they start.”Trump has repeatedly claimed that he has solved 8 wars across the globe, including brokering a ceasefire between India and Pakistan during the May standoff by threatening them with 350 per cent tariffs.Trump further argued that tariffs are vital to the US economy and security. “There is almost no Inflation, and the worst in USA History under Sleepy Joe Biden,” he said, adding, “The Stock Market just hit an ALL-TIME HIGH for the 48th time in 9 months.”Turning to his critics, Trump targeted Federalist Society leader Leonard Leo, the Koch network, and foreign governments for “ripping off" the US through the use of their own tariffs.Trump’s criticism of Leo follows a public fallout earlier this year. In May, he attacked his once ally after the US Court of International Trade struck down his tariffs, calling him a “sleazebag” who “probably hates America.”The latest remarks add to Trump’s ongoing defence of his tariff-driven agenda, which he continues to frame as central to US strength both at home and abroad.
Article Summary: US President Donald Trump once again defended his aggressive tariff strategy. He claimed it is generating “TRILLIONS of Dollars” for America and has functioned as a powerful tool to prevent international conflicts. Trump has repeatedly claimed that he has solved 8 wars across the globe, including brokering a ceasefire between India and Pakistan.

Article Title: Manufacturing slowdown: US factory activity slows as tariffs push up prices; services sector cushions overall growth
Article Text:
AI image

Manufacturing hit by rising prices and weak demand



Tariffs squeeze households, sentiment weakens



Services sector keeps overall activity steady



US manufacturing slipped to a four-month low in November as tariffs pushed up prices and dampened demand.According to news agency Reuters, the slowdown caused a build-up of unsold goods, raising concerns that it may drag down wider economic growth.S&P Global said the flash US manufacturing PMI eased to 51.9 from 52.5 in October, with new orders dropping to 51.3 and inventories rising to the highest level recorded in the survey.Chris Williamson of S&P Global Market Intelligence said manufacturers faced “a worrying combination of slower new orders growth and a record rise in finished goods stock,” cautioning that output may weaken further unless demand revives.Reuters reported that consumers are increasingly reluctant to buy long-lasting manufactured goods. The University of Michigan’s latest survey showed a sharp fall in purchasing conditions, adding that “consumers remain frustrated about the persistence of high prices and weakening incomes.”US President Donald Trump’s tariffs have pushed up import costs, placing additional pressure on lower- and middle-income families.A recent stock-market sell-off has also dented confidence among wealthier Americans, who had earlier supported spending.Economist Sung Won Sohn was quoted by Reuters as saying that those at the lower-income end “will probably not spend very much,” adding that uncertainty in markets “is going to hurt even the spending of wealthier people, especially retirees.”Despite the factory-sector slowdown, broader business activity remained solid.The US Composite PMI Output Index rose to 54.8, supported by a stronger services sector. Reuters reported that services PMI climbed to 55.0, driven by better new business orders and improved confidence linked to expectations of further rate cuts, the end of the 43-day government shutdown and easing political concerns.Consumer sentiment inched up to 51 in the University of Michigan survey, though it stayed below October’s level. Joanne Hsu, who heads the survey, said sentiment among households with large stock holdings dropped due to late-month market declines.Inflation pressures remained elevated, with businesses reporting higher input costs and increased prices for goods and services.Consumers also expect stronger inflation in the next year, Reuters said, even as five-year expectations eased slightly to 3.4%.Though the PMI suggested no sharp deterioration in the labour market, hiring softened marginally, with private-sector employment slipping to 51.0 amid tariff-related cost concerns.
Article Summary: US manufacturing slipped to a four-month low in November as tariffs pushed up prices and dampened demand. The slowdown caused a build-up of unsold goods, raising concerns that it may drag down wider economic growth. Despite the factory-sector slowdown, broader business activity remained solid, supported by a stronger services sector.

Article Title: IPO market cools after shutdown: US listings slow as SEC backlog delays approvals; tech slump adds pressure
Article Text:
Several recent IPOs have lost momentum after strong debuts

Broader markets weigh on sentiment

Investor appetite remains strong despite volatility

Key IPO candidates for 2026 include Databricks, Canva, and Plaid, AP reported.

The strong run in US initial public offerings has lost momentum due to the government shutdown and increased investor caution, as the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) works through a backlog of regulatory filings, according to market participants.Many IPOs expected in late 2025 are likely to be pushed to 2026 as the SEC clears “hundreds of registration statements,” AP reported. Listings that did debut recently have seen limited gains amid concerns that stocks have become expensive following another year of double-digit market returns.“A backlogged SEC, the approaching holiday slowdown, and pressure on AI and other tech stocks are all weighing on hopes for a near-term rebound,” Bill Smith, CEO of Renaissance Capital, said in a note to investors.Despite delays, several IPOs already advanced through the regulatory pipeline are expected to list in November and December.Central Bancompany, which went public after the shutdown, raised $373 million through its IPO on Thursday. November remains on track to be among the slowest IPO months of 2025, Renaissance Capital said.Upcoming large listings could include medical supplies company Medline, potentially raising up to $5 billion in December, while cryptocurrency technology firm BitGo also remains a candidate for a listing next month.Shares of Figma, which tripled on debut after pricing at $33 per share in July, are now trading slightly above their IPO price. Swedish buy-now-pay-later firm Klarna, priced at $40 in September, is now trading near $29.Cloud services company CoreWeave, listed at $40 in March, jumped initially but has retreated to around $72. Software firm Navan, listed at $25 during the shutdown, is now trading near $15.The S&P 500 has fallen 3.5% in November, driven by a slide in technology shares following concerns about valuations tied to artificial-intelligence-linked stocks. However, the index is still up more than 12% this year, while the Nasdaq has gained over 15%.Renaissance Capital’s IPO Index is down about 0.8% this year and has lagged the S&P 500 since mid-October.“What that shows is that investors very quickly monetized, they didn't want to take the long-term risk,” said Samuel Kerr, head of global equity capital markets at Mergermarket.Analysts say high valuations in public markets may continue to push investors toward IPOs as alternative entry points.“Increasingly, as a money manager, you have to find other places to make money and typically, IPOs are that place,” said David Kaufman, partner and co-chair of the corporate & securities practice at Thompson Coburn LLP, AP quoted. “You continue to have all these large mutual funds and money managers with excess cash and no place to put this cash.”The slowdown masks a surge in behind-the-scenes activity, Kaufman added: “It’s a busy time for lawyers and bankers trying to tee things up for the first and second quarter of next year.”
Article Summary: Many IPOs expected in late 2025 are likely to be pushed to 2026. Listings that did debut recently have seen limited gains amid concerns that stocks have become expensive. November remains on track to be among the slowest IPO months of 2025.

Article Title: Are we all living inside an AI bubble? Inside circular deals and the quiet financial loop they created
Article Text:
What does it mean?

and are we in an

AI bubble

?

OpenAI's Master Plan for India

Inside the loop: What are circular Deals





The loop is tight, lucrative, and increasingly enormous.

But why do they exist?

So are we in a bubble?





first need to look at the scale of the investments:

A market bigger than pharma

OpenAI’s revenue and the pricing question





Would raising prices fix OpenAI’s financial pressure?

How Oracle became an unlikely winner





Oracle invests in the infrastructure OpenAI needs.

OpenAI commits to spending billions on Oracle Cloud to run its models.

Oracle gains a marquee client and a narrative shift that boosts investor confidence.

Echoes of the dot-com bubble - and what burst it





It wasn’t one factor it was a cluster of external shocks:

Antitrust action against Microsoft: The US government’s lawsuit rattled confidence in the entire tech sector. The perception of regulatory overreach pushed investors to reassess risk. Corporate accounting scandals: MicroStrategy famously restated its financial results, triggering panic around revenue inflation across the industry. The broader macro unwind: The housing market began showing cracks; interest rates shifted; capital costs rose. Companies dependent on cheap financing suddenly found credit scarce. Telecom overbuild and bad debt: Cisco, Lucent and others extended supplier financing to customers who were effectively insolvent. When those loans went bad, the write-downs cascaded.

Has AI faced a similar shock yet?





Regulatory scrutiny has been loud but not existential.

OpenAI’s internal governance turmoil did not derail the company.

Supply chain shortages have slowed but not stopped GPU availability.

High interest rates have not dried up capital for AI megaprojects.

So, this is sustainable?





Investors are split.

The bullish case

AI is transformative Compute demand is compounding Early investment will pay off across decades Circular deals are simply a modern way to bootstrap hyper-scale infrastructure

The bearish case

The sector’s valuations rely on uninterrupted optimism Cash flows are disguised by internal loops Capital expenditure requirements are too high for current revenue One external shock could trigger cascading losses

A revolution built on a loop





Three years ago, generative AI was barely on anyone’s radar. Three months ago, circular deals were whispered about only in private meetings at big banks. Weeks and days ago, these loops were still a niche topic. Today, they are all anyone on Wall Street can talk about.As investments swell: from $100 billion chip deals to multi-gigawatt data-centre projects, questions are mounting.The first question is:A growing number of AI firms and their partners are engaging in “circular” financing, a loop in which the same companies that pour money into AI start-ups are also the ones selling them the infrastructure they need to survive.It has created what can be described as an ouroboros ecosystem, a self-feeding financial creature devouring its own tail. And as the numbers balloon from $100 billion chip deals to multi-gigawatt data-centre projects questions are rising about how sustainable this loop really is.Circular deals are straightforward in theory but unusually powerful in practice. An AI company receives immense investment from a tech giant and then commits to spending that money back with the same investor on cloud compute, chips, and infrastructure.Take one of the clearest examples: Microsoft and Nvidia’s multi-billion-dollar commitments to Anthropic. The start-up received around $15 billion from the two giants, but simultaneously committed to spend $30 billion on Microsoft’s Azure cloud and Nvidia GPUs. On paper, it looks like a huge show of confidence in Anthropic. In reality, a large portion of that investment will flow straight back into the pockets of Microsoft and Nvidia via long-term infrastructure contracts. OpenAI , the sector’s flagship, takes this circularity even further. Nvidia has reportedly pledged up to $100 billion in investment; OpenAI, in turn, is one of the largest buyers of Nvidia GPUs on the planet. AMD struck similar agreements, providing next-generation chips while granting OpenAI warrants that allow it to buy a stake in AMD for a symbolic price meaning OpenAI pays AMD for hardware while simultaneously holding equity that benefits if AMD succeeds.Meanwhile, Oracle is deeply embedded as OpenAI’s cloud backend. The two companies are building new AI super-data-centres under a partnership nominally worth over $300 billion. OpenAI receives compute capacity now but is committed to paying Oracle roughly the same amount over the next five years.SoftBank’s arrangements with OpenAI operate in the same space: it injects capital into the company and simultaneously builds infrastructure for OpenAI’s Stargate project, which OpenAI then commits to paying for across the next decade.The AI boom’s most limited resource is not talent or data, it's computers. Training frontier AI models requires hundreds of thousands of GPUs and vast amounts of power.This is why many deals are measured not in dollars but in gigawatts (GW).A single gigawatt is a staggering unit:1 GW ≈ the electricity consumption of 750,000 homes.Next-generation AI data centres increasingly require sites of 1–4 GW each. OpenAI’s planned megasite in Texas is expected to consume power on the scale of a small country. These sites need dedicated substations, transmission lines, cooling farms and, in some cases, on-site power generation.Because the capital expenditure is so immense, AI companies need partners that can supply cash and infrastructure. Cloud providers and chipmakers fit the bill but they recoup their investment by locking start-ups into massive, long-term spending commitments.The economics are daunting: McKinsey estimates that meeting global AI compute demand will require $7 trillion in capital expenditure by 2030. Bain has issued similar warnings, noting that the gap between current AI revenue and required future revenue to sustain that expenditure is in the hundreds of billions annually.A simple way to answer whether there is an AI bubble is to start with the generative models themselves. For example, when ChatGPT is asked, “Are we in an AI bubble?” it responds: “Yes, (in the short term).”“Short-term: Yes, there’s over-exuberance. Some of the money is flowing into speculative plays, and not every AI startup will survive,” ChatGPT opined.“Medium to Long-term: Even if there’s a “pop” or correction, I don’t think AI goes away. The infrastructure (data centers, chips, cloud) and real use-cases are likely to persist and mature,” it said in its long term prediction.Elon Musk's Grok agreed that we are in an AI bubble but offered an optimistic view, saying it’s not “the kind that will inevitably end in total catastrophe like the dot-com crash or 2008.”“Yes, I think we're in an AI bubble—though not the kind that will inevitably end in total catastrophe like the dot-com crash or 2008. It's more like a frothy, speculative swell built on genuine technological promise, where valuations have raced ahead of near-term realities, and a correction feels overdue,” Musk’s chatbot said.Gemini described the current moment as a small bubble of investor excitement sitting on top of a much larger, long-term technological shift. In its view, only weaker players and short-term bets are at risk, because the underlying technology remains solid.But to really understand if there is a bubble, weNothing illustrates the speculative scale better than Nvidia. The company’s market capitalisation is now larger than the entire global pharmaceutical industry combined. The comparison is striking:Pharma is a century-old sector with regulated demand, stable revenue and essential products.Nvidia is riding a single theme - AI compute whose long-term commercial returns are still unproven.Investors have embraced the idea that AI will reshape the global economy. But the sheer size of these valuations has led some analysts to warn that even small disappointments in AI adoption could trigger disproportionately large corrections.This is one reason high-profile investors like Michael Burry famous for “The Big Short” have reportedly shorted companies tied closely to the AI boom, including OpenAI-related plays and Palantir. His bearish stance signals that not everyone is convinced the sector can sustain its current velocity.OpenAI reportedly generated around $12 billion in annual revenue. That figure represents enormous traction for an eight-year-old company but its operating costs still exceed its income. Training frontier models like GPT-5 costs billions, and inference expenses (the cost of running the models) rise with user demand.This raises an uncomfortable question:Possibly but at a cost.OpenAI’s mainstream foothold depends heavily on consumer adoption and developer usage. Its subscription tiers, API pricing and enterprise contracts are designed to drive volume, not maximise margin. A significant price hike could slow the growth that its entire valuation depends on.Moreover, the company faces fierce competition: Anthropic, Google DeepMind, Meta, Mistral, and a rapidly rising open-source ecosystem. In a market shaped by hype and experimentation, raising prices too aggressively risks sending developers elsewhere.Thus OpenAI is caught in the classic innovator’s dilemma:Charge more and risk losing scale, or maintain low prices and burn cash.Oracle might appear an unusual beneficiary of the AI boom but its entanglement with OpenAI is one of the most strategic plays in the industry.Oracle’s cloud business historically lagged behind AWS, Azure and Google Cloud. Enter AI: the OpenAI partnership has repositioned Oracle as a critical provider of GPU capacity, filling its data centres with high-margin compute workloads.The $300 billion-plus partnership is effectively a circular loop:The arrangement is lucrative but also risky. If AI growth slows, Oracle could be left with overbuilt infrastructure, echoing the telecom overcapacity of the dot-com era.The parallels with the late-1990s tech boom are more than rhetorical. The mechanism is similar: companies inflated each other’s valuations through investment loops and customer financing schemes.But the more important lesson comes from why the dot-com bubble burst.What killed the dot-com boom was not the failure of the technology, it was the collapse of the financial scaffolding.AI is now building an even bigger, more interconnected one.So far, the AI sector has weathered every potential disruption:In other words: the external shock hasn’t arrived yet.But history suggests that when investment loops are this tightly interwoven, it only takes one disruption, a regulatory hit, a liquidity crunch, an accounting scandal, or a sudden slowdown in AI adoption for the system to reprice violently.In this sense, the AI boom stands at a crossroads similar to 1999–2000: dazzling technological promise intertwined with fragile financial engineering.Circular AI financing is brilliant, aggressive and deeply risky. It has enabled the fastest infrastructure build-out in tech history, compressed into just a few years. But it has also created a tightly coupled financial ecosystem where companies invest in each other, buy from each other and depend heavily on mutual success.If AI delivers the productivity surge its champions predict, the investment loops will look visionary. If it falters, the ouroboros may finally bite too hard and unravel the most expensive technology cycle in a generation.Time, and perhaps an external shock, will reveal which way the loop bends.
Article Summary: A growing number of AI firms and their partners are engaging in ‘circular’ financing, a loop in which the same companies that pour money into AI start-ups are also selling them the infrastructure they need to survive. It has created what can be described as an ouroboros ecosystem, a self-feeding financial creature devouring its own tail.

Article Title: Shutdown fallout: US scraps October inflation and jobs figures after data-gathering halt; gaps cloud Fed’s December decision
Article Text:
File photo (Picture credit: AP)

US Shutdown ‘Ends’ After 40 Days; Senate Passes Bill After Dems ‘COMPROMISE’ With House GOP | WATCH

The US government will not release official inflation or jobs figures for October after the record-long shutdown prevented statisticians from gathering essential data, leaving the Federal Reserve without two major indicators ahead of its December policy meeting.The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) confirmed on Friday that the October consumer price index (CPI) has been cancelled because staff were unable to collect the survey information in time, as per Reuters.“BLS is unable to retroactively collect these data,” the agency said, adding that only a few indexes based on nonsurvey data could be reconstructed. Where possible, October values will be issued alongside November’s CPI report on 18 December.The shutdown—which lasted 43 days from early October to mid-November—also forced the cancellation of the October employment report.While October nonfarm payroll figures will be combined with November data on 16 December, the unemployment rate for that month “will never be known”, reported Reuters.A similar message was delivered in Washington on Friday, with the BLS reiterating that survey-based data simply “was not gathered” during the stoppage, reported news agency AFP.The agency noted that CPI collection typically relies on in-person visits to retailers, including supermarkets, and telephone interviews. Household survey data for the jobs report is gathered in the same way.The cancellations have intensified uncertainty for the Federal Reserve, which meets on 9–10 December.Fed Chair Jerome Powell recently compared navigating the economy without standard datasets to “driving in the fog”, reported The Guardian.“What do you do if you’re driving in the fog? You slow down,” he said last month.Fed officials were already under pressure, with inflation still above typical levels and policymakers weighing whether to deliver another rate cut.A speech by New York Fed President John Williams on Friday added to expectations of a possible adjustment, saying he saw “room for a further adjustment in the near term”, according to The Guardian.The September jobs report, released with delays because of the shutdown, showed 119,000 jobs added but the unemployment rate rising to its highest level since 2021.The full October labour market report will never be published, although the job creation figure for that month will appear alongside November’s release a week after the Fed’s meeting.The shutdown has already pushed back a series of economic indicators, including retail sales and trade data, as per AFP.It comes as President Donald Trump’s tariffs continue to complicate inflation pressures, with some Fed officials considering holding rates steady for longer.
Article Summary: US government will not release official inflation or jobs figures for October after record-long shutdown. Bureau of Labor Statistics confirmed on Friday that the October consumer price index (CPI) has been cancelled because staff were unable to collect the survey information in time. October values will be issued alongside November’s CPI report on 18 December.

Article Title: US court enters $1 billion default judgment against Byju Raveendran
Article Text:
File photo: Byju Raveendran (Picture credit: IANS)

BENGALURU: The Delaware Bankruptcy Court has entered a default judgment of more than $1.07 billion against Byju Raveendran, after finding that the edtech founder repeatedly failed to comply with court-ordered discovery in the Byju’s Alpha adversary proceeding.A default judgment is a ruling issued when a party does not participate in the litigation or ignores court orders, allowing the court to decide the case without a trial.The ruling, issued on November 20 and reviewed by TOI, awards $533 million in damages for what the court described as fraudulent transfer of Byju’s Alpha’s funds in 2022, and another $540.6 million tied to the transfer of the debtor’s interest in Camshaft Capital Fund, a US hedge fund.The court also ordered Raveendran to provide a “full and accurate accounting” of the Alpha Funds and any proceeds that flowed from subsequent transactions.Judge Brendan Shannon wrote that the relief granted was “extraordinary” but justified, citing what he called an “extensive and repeated pattern of delay and obfuscation.”The order recounts multiple missed deadlines, incomplete filings, non-appearances, and non-payment of earlier sanctions, including a $10,000-per-day fine imposed in July for civil contempt.The adversary case was brought by Byju’s Alpha Inc., the US unit currently in Chapter 11 bankruptcy, along with GLAS Trust, the loan agent that now controls the debtor.They allege that more than half a billion dollars was “spirited away” from the company and routed through various entities beyond the reach of creditors. Raveendran has denied wrongdoing in earlier filings and has argued that discovery requests were improper or unnecessary; the court rejected those objections.The judgment comes alongside a separate filing earlier this week in which the bankruptcy estate submitted a sworn declaration from UK businessman Oliver Chapman, describing how the disputed funds allegedly moved through his firm, OCI Limited, before being routed to a Singapore entity the debtor claims was linked to Raveendran.That motion seeks court approval for a settlement with Chapman and marks the most detailed account yet submitted to the court on the alleged movement of the Alpha Funds.The defense further claimed that “the monies from the Alpha loans were not used by Byju Raveendran or any founder for their personal gain but were used for the benefit of Think & Learn Private Limited (TLPL).”It alleged that GLAS Trust “has been aware” of this, and accuses the lender-appointed agent of “misleading” the Delaware court.Raveendran’s lawyers added that he and other founders are preparing US federal claims alleging “racketeering and obstruction of justice,” seeking not less than $2.5 billion in damages and said these actions will be filed “before the end of 2025.”
Article Summary: Delaware Bankruptcy Court has entered a default judgment of more than $1.07 billion against Byju Raveendran. The court found that the edtech founder repeatedly failed to comply with court-ordered discovery in the Byju’s Alpha adversary proceeding.

Article Title: Data blackout: US scraps October CPI report after govt shutdown; Fed left without key data ahead of policy meet
Article Text:
Fed to decide policy without fresh inflation or jobs data

The US government will not publish consumer inflation data for October after a 43-day federal shutdown disrupted data collection, intensifying uncertainty ahead of the Federal Reserve’s December policy meeting.The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) said it “is unable to retroactively collect” consumer price data for October and will not release the report originally scheduled for November 13, AFP reported.The shutdown, which lasted from October to mid-November, also halted publications on key indicators including trade and retail sales. Earlier this week, the BLS said it would not release an October jobs report because unemployment survey data was not collected.The delays mean the Federal Reserve will not have updated readings on inflation or labour market conditions when policymakers meet on December 9-10. Available employment data from October will instead be released alongside November’s numbers after the meeting, according to AFP.Analysts say the absence of fresh data complicates the central bank’s balancing act between inflation risks and a slowing labour market. A prolonged downturn in hiring could strengthen the case for further rate cuts, while tariff-driven price pressures may argue for a pause.President Donald Trump ’s tariff measures have made bringing inflation down more challenging, prompting some Fed policymakers to signal caution about cutting rates too quickly, AFP noted.
Article Summary: US government will not publish consumer inflation data for October after a 43-day federal shutdown disrupted data collection. Federal Reserve will not have updated readings on inflation or labour market conditions when policymakers meet on December 9-10. Earlier this week, the BLS said it would not release an October jobs report because unemployment survey data was not collected.

Article Title: Crypto crash: Bitcoin sinks below $82k; tech slump spills into crypto markets-here's what analysts say
Article Text:
$1.2 trillion crypto value wiped out

Corporate crypto holdings under pressure

Bitcoin and ether tumbled to multi-month lows on Friday as investors pulled back from riskier assets amid concerns over stretched tech valuations and fading expectations of near-term US rate cuts, Reuters reported.Bitcoin, the world’s largest cryptocurrency , dropped 5.5% to a seven-month low of $81,668, while ether slid more than 6% to $2,661.37, hitting a four-month low.Both tokens have fallen roughly 12% this week, erasing Bitcoin’s year-to-date gains and pulling ether nearly 19% lower for the year.The sell-off comes as volatility spikes across equity markets, particularly high-flying artificial intelligence stocks. Analysts said the retreat signals a broader shift away from speculative assets. “If it’s telling a story about risk sentiment as a whole, then things could start to get really, really ugly, and that’s the concern now,” said Tony Sycamore, market analyst at IG, according to Reuters.The market value of all cryptocurrencies has dropped by about $1.2 trillion in six weeks, CoinGecko data showed. Shares of Hong Kong-listed spot bitcoin ETFs from China AMC, Harvest and Bosera fell close to 7% on Friday.Bitcoin’s fall follows a rally earlier this year that pushed it above $120,000 in October, driven by favourable regulatory developments. However, analysts say last month’s record one-day crash — which triggered $19 billion in liquidations — has left sentiment fragile. “The market feels a little bit dislocated, a bit fractured, a bit broken,” Sycamore said, quoted Reuters.Citi analyst Alex Saunders noted that $80,000 is a key level because it is close to the average purchase price of ETF-held bitcoin.The downturn has dragged crypto-linked stocks lower. Strategy, once seen as a flagship corporate bitcoin accumulator, has fallen 11% this week and traded near one-year lows, Reuters said. JP Morgan warned the firm could be removed from some MSCI equity indices, potentially forcing index-linked funds to sell.Japan-based Metaplanet has plunged about 80% from its June peak, while crypto exchange Coinbase is on track for its longest losing streak in over a month. Miners MARA Holdings and CleanSpark dropped 2.4% and 3.6%, respectively, and newly listed Gemini has sunk 62% from its debut.Digital asset research firm CryptoQuant said conditions were deteriorating sharply. “Bitcoin market conditions are the most bearish they have been since the current bull cycle started in January 2023,” it said, adding that “we are highly likely to have seen most of this cycle’s demand wave pass.”
Article Summary: World's largest cryptocurrency drops 5.5% to a seven-month low of $81,668. Ether slides more than 6% to $2,661.37, hitting a four-monthLow. Both tokens have fallen roughly 12% this week, erasing Bitcoin’s year-to-date gains.

Article Title: From 'Widow-Maker' to market shaker: Why Japan’s bonds are sending shockwaves globally
Article Text:
AI image means for representation only

1. What is happening in the bond market, and why the global panic?

2. Japan has always had high debt. Why is it a problem now?

3. Why is the "Widow-Maker" trade finally working?

Ended negative interest rates.

Scrapped its "Yield Curve Control" policy.

Hiked the policy rate to 0.5%, a 17-year high.

4. The "Carry Trade" is unraveling. What does that mean?

Borrowing yen becomes expensive.

The yen strengthens against the dollar.

5. What are bond investors actually seeing that scares them?

6. The vicious cycle risk

Higher costs : The government has to spend more of its budget just to pay interest on existing debt.

: The government has to spend more of its budget just to pay interest on existing debt. Balance sheet pain : Japanese banks and insurers hold massive amounts of these bonds; as yields rise, the value of those bonds falls, hurting their financial health.

: Japanese banks and insurers hold massive amounts of these bonds; as yields rise, the value of those bonds falls, hurting their financial health. More borrowing: To pay the higher interest, the government might borrow more, which pushes yields up further.

7. Fighting inflation by spending money? Isn’t that contradictory?

8. What does this mean for India and Emerging Markets?

9. Crisis or Correction?

The Crisis View : The combination of debt, stimulus, and rising rates will eventually break the market.

: The combination of debt, stimulus, and rising rates will eventually break the market. The Normalization Vie w: Japan is simply catching up to the rest of the world after decades of stagnation.

w: Japan is simply catching up to the rest of the world after decades of stagnation. The Middle Path: A messy transition where the government tolerates slightly higher inflation to inflate away some of the debt.

(With inputs from agencies)

Japan currently finds itself stuck between a rock and a hard place. On the geopolitical front, Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi’s hawkish stance linking Taiwan’s security to Japan’s own has ruffled feathers in Beijing. China has already fired back with economic warnings—from freezing film approvals to squeezing seafood imports—signaling that Tokyo is in a delicate diplomatic bind.But the real storm is brewing at home. In a bid to soothe a public weary of inflation, the government is unleashing a massive stimulus package worth ¥21.3 trillion (roughly $135 billion). While the cash injection might help voters, it’s rattling a bond market that was already on edge. With the Bank of Japan (BoJ) stepping back and interest rates creeping up, bond yields are hitting levels not seen since the 2008 financial crisis.This marks the end of the ultra-loose monetary policy that defined Japan for decades. Now, analysts are asking the uncomfortable question: Can the world’s most indebted nation manage its towering debt without breaking something in the global financial system?Here is an explainer on why Japan’s bond market has suddenly become the world's biggest worry.Simply put, Japanese Government Bond (JGB) yields are breaking out. The 10-year yield recently flirted with 1.8%—a high water mark not seen since 2008—while the 30-year yield pushed past 3.3%. For a country where "zero interest" was the status quo for a generation, this is a seismic shift.Why it matters: Japan isn't just any economy; it is the world’s largest creditor nation. Japanese investors have trillions of dollars parked in global assets, from US Treasuries to Australian real estate. If domestic bonds suddenly offer a decent return, that money might pack its bags and head back to Tokyo. This repatriation of capital could drain liquidity from markets like the US and India, causing ripple effects everywhere.Japan’s debt-to-GDP ratio has sat around 230% for years without causing a crisis. The difference today is the timing.The government is launching a massive ¥21.3 trillion spending spree to fight inflation exactly when the central bank is trying to stop buying so many bonds. Usually, central banks buy bonds to keep yields low; with the BoJ stepping back, the market has to absorb this new debt, pushing yields up.As Mizuho’s Saori Tsuiki noted, the sheer size of the stimulus sends a risky message. If the market believes the government has lost its fiscal discipline, investors might discount the economic benefits entirely, leaving Japan with just the debt and none of the growth.For decades, shorting Japanese bonds (betting that yields would rise) was nicknamed the "widow-maker" trade. Traders who tried it got wiped out because the Bank of Japan had an unlimited checkbook to keep yields at zero.But the widow-maker has finally woken up. Over the last year, the BoJ has:As Bloomberg put it, we are watching a market that was artificially engineered by a central bank trying to learn how to be a "normal" market again. The safety net is gone.The carry trade was the financial world’s favorite free lunch. Investors borrowed yen cheaply (because Japanese rates were zero), converted it to dollars, and bought higher-yielding assets like US stocks or Indian bonds.However, as Japanese yields rise, two things happen:This destroys the profit margin of the trade. Investors are now forced to sell their foreign assets to pay back their yen loans—a process called "unwinding." This is why a small rate hike in Tokyo can trigger a massive sell-off in the S&P 500.The "bond vigilantes" are spotting cracks in the foundation. Recent auctions for long-term bonds (20 to 40 years) have seen weak demand, a clear sign that investors are hesitant to lend to the government long-term.Investors know that defense spending and social security costs are only going up. S&P Global Ratings analyst Rain Yin pointed out that Japan faces undeniable spending pressure on these fronts. If the government has to issue record amounts of debt to pay for it, and there are fewer buyers, yields have nowhere to go but up.If yields keep rising, it creates a nasty feedback loop:Yes, and that is exactly why economists are raising eyebrows.The government claims it is trying to thread a needle—supporting the economy without fueling inflation. But pouring cash into an economy struggling with high prices usually just fans the flames. Yuichi Kodama of Meiji Yasuda suggests this might be political theater: the spending is likely a way for the Takaichi administration to show they care about the public’s struggle, even if it risks spooking the markets.India is in the blast radius. If Japanese yields become attractive, Japanese funds might pull capital out of Indian bonds and equities. Furthermore, as the "carry trade" unwinds, global investors tend to go "risk-off," pulling money out of emerging markets to cover their losses elsewhere. This often leads to volatility in the rupee and Indian stock indices.Is this the big crash, or just a return to normalcy? There are three main views:Most analysts expect a mix of all three. But one thing is certain: the days of ignoring Japan’s bond market are over. It has gone from a predictable sleeper to a source of potential global volatility.
Article Summary: Japanese bond yields are hitting levels not seen since the 2008 financial crisis. The 10-year yield recently flirted with 1.8%, while the 30-year yields pushed past 3.3%. This marks the end of the ultra-loose monetary policy that defined Japan for decades.

Article Title: Nvidia chip smuggling: Four charged in US over illegal exports to China; lawmakers urge stricter rules
Article Text:
Representative image

Defendants, charges and alleged methods



Legislative response and strategic concerns



The US justice department has charged four individuals in a scheme to illegally export Nvidia AI chips to China, highlighting challenges in enforcing US high-tech export restrictions.The indictment, unsealed Thursday in US district court in Tampa, Florida, accuses two US citizens and two Chinese nationals of conspiring to ship Nvidia GPUs without required licenses, using fake contracts and false documentation to disguise shipments through Malaysia and Thailand.According to court documents, 400 Nvidia A100 GPUs were successfully exported to China between October 2024 and January 2025, while attempts to export 10 Hewlett-Packard supercomputers with H100 GPUs and 50 H200 GPUs were stopped by law enforcement, reported CNBC.The scheme allegedly used a Tampa company, Janford Realtor, as a front for the transactions, funded with nearly $4 million in wire transfers from China.One defendant, Brian Curtis Raymond, 46, from Huntsville, Alabama, is identified as the former CTO of an AI cloud company in Virginia, which confirmed he is no longer employed there, reported CNBC.Raymond, along with co-defendant Mathew Ho (Hon Ning Ho), 34, a US citizen born in Hong Kong, allegedly coordinated the shipments, knowing the chips would ultimately be sent to China.Two other defendants, Jing (Harry) Chen, 45, and Tony Li, 38, both Chinese nationals, are also charged.Charges include conspiracy to violate the Export Control Reform Act (ECRA), smuggling, and multiple counts of money laundering related to the $3.4–$4 million in wire transfers.Raymond faces seven money laundering counts and additional ECRA violations; Ho faces nine money laundering counts, four ECRA violations, and three smuggling counts.Chen and Li face conspiracy, ECRA violations, and smuggling charges. All four could face up to 20 years in prison if convicted.The case has renewed calls from US lawmakers for stricter chip-tracking legislation.John Moolenaar, chair of the House Select Committee on China, stressed the need for the bipartisan Chip Security Act, which would mandate chip location verification and reporting of potential diversions.“China recognises the superiority of American AI innovation and will do whatever it must to catch up. That’s why the bipartisan Chip Security Act is urgently needed,” he said, as per Reuters.The indictment underlines the strategic importance of AI and supercomputing chips, which US export curbs aim to prevent from aiding China’s military and technological advancements.The justice department noted that China is actively developing exascale supercomputing capabilities and plans to become a global AI leader by 2030.
Article Summary: The indictment, unsealed Thursday in US district court in Tampa, Florida, accuses two US citizens and two Chinese nationals of conspiring to ship Nvidia GPUs without required licenses. The scheme allegedly used a Tampa company, Janford Realtor, as a front for the transactions, funded with nearly $4 million in wire transfers from China. All four could face up to 20 years in prison if convicted.

Article Title: US markets today: Wall Street steadies after sharp reversal; AI stocks remain volatile as Bitcoin slump deepens
Article Text: US stocks recovered on Friday after a volatile week, with major indices rising on renewed expectations of a December interest-rate cut amid sharp swings in artificial intelligence-linked and cryptocurrency assets.The S&P 500 climbed 1.2% in early trade, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 709 points, or 1.6%. The Nasdaq composite rose 1% after fluctuating through the morning session, AP reported.The rebound followed comments by Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams, who told a conference in Chile that he sees “room for a further adjustment” in policy rates, signalling possible support for another reduction at the Federal Reserve’s meeting next month.The Associated Press reported that markets rallied immediately after his remarks, even as other Fed officials have argued against additional easing due to persistent inflationary pressures.Despite Friday’s gains, AI-linked stocks continued to trade with sharp swings. Nvidia fell 4.3% after reversing an early rise, while Amazon recovered from initial losses to gain 1.4%.Bitcoin briefly slipped below $81,000 before rebounding to around $85,000.The cryptocurrency has fallen from nearly $125,000 last month and is back to levels last seen in April when markets reacted to tariff announcements by President Donald Trump, AP reported.Broader market strength came from retail stocks, with Gap jumping 9.4% after posting stronger-than-expected quarterly profit across Old Navy, Gap and Banana Republic brands. Ross Stores rose 7.7% after raising holiday season sales guidance.Homebuilders gained on hopes that lower rates could revive demand for housing, with D.R. Horton rising 7.4%, PulteGroup up 6.2% and Lennar gaining 6.2%.The yield on the 10-year US Treasury slipped to 4.08% from 4.10% a day earlier, while CME Group data showed traders pricing nearly a 70% probability of a December cut—up from 39% the previous day.Sentiment improved further after the University of Michigan consumer survey showed easing inflation expectations for both the short and long term, a trend analysts say could give the Fed more flexibility to ease monetary policy.European markets were mixed after Thursday’s sharp losses, while Asia saw deeper declines. Japan’s Nikkei 225 fell 2.4% and South Korea’s Kospi dropped 3.8%, while Hang Seng and Shanghai indices also remained under pressure.
